summary: The document provides an in-depth look at the CIA's budget allocation for contract employees in 1974, highlighting the distinctions between staff and contract employees in terms of salaries and benefits. It also examines the CIA's connection to the Watergate burglary, detailing the involvement levels of various individuals associated with the CIA and the agency's response to investigations into the matter. The CIA's cooperation with investigations, including document provision and testimony, is noted, alongside the clarification that no further CIA personnel involvement in Watergate has been discovered.
key_findings: The CIA allocated $279.5 million for staff employees and $32.6 million for contract employees in its 1974 budget.
Participation in the Watergate burglary included one part-time contract employee, one former full-time contract employee, two retired staff employees, and three individuals with no CIA connection.
Contract employees' subjection to controls varies based on their contract type, differing from regular staff employees.
The CIA has actively cooperated with Watergate investigations by providing necessary documents and testimony, with no additional CIA personnel involvement uncovered.
